item.title: Minimum CSS
item.author: mail@thisdaysportion.com
item.description:
I came across a blog with 147 lines of CSS today, including a couple of font-face declarations and a handful of custom properties. It looked pretty good and was perfectly readable, which is a testament to the author‚Äôs skill and judgement, the expressiveness of CSS and the robustness of browser defaults.

This sort of thing always gets me thinking about the minimum CSS required to publish a blog. You might start by arguing the answer to that question is none at all, and, strictly speaking, that‚Äôs true. Browsers style markup without you lifting a finger by putting margins between things, bolding, italicising, colouring links and lots of other things. You can even add a single line to your website‚Äôs head and get light and dark modes thrown in.

If you take that approach you will hit on one problem, especially on a mobile. Any wide image will extend beyond the edge of the screen. You‚Äôll still be able to see the whole image by scrolling horizontally, but that‚Äôs a pretty rubbish experience for your readers. So the bare minimum CSS is this:

img {
	max-inline-size: 100% !important;
	block-size: auto !important;
}

Four lines. Sort of. If you want this to work with browsers that don‚Äôt understand logical properties like block-size, you‚Äôll need to add a few more lines to set maximum width and height, check whether the browser supports logical properties with supports and, if it does, unset the maximum width and height and finally add the above lines.

It can get verbose quite quickly.

Still, that‚Äôs cool ‚Äî a few lines of CSS and you‚Äôve got a responsive website that doesn‚Äôt bork on a mobile. Except it‚Äôs not particularly readable on a laptop, even less so on a desktop monitor, what with everything extending across the whole of the screen. A comfortable line length (or measure) is ‚Äî well, that‚Äôs a matter of art and science, conjecture, and dependent on a bunch of contextual factors, such as the language we‚Äôre writing in, font metrics and the nature of the text itself ‚Äî but it‚Äôs definitely less than the width of your desktop monitor.

Which means you should probably add some CSS that stops lines getting too long:

body {
	max-inline-size: 60ch;
}

But as we know, not every browser will understand max-inline-size (or ch for that matter), so you might want to do the max-width and supports dance again. Or, like me, you might reach a compromise and set a few basic readability rules that work on pretty much any browser on earth, and accept that readers using older or more obscure browsers miss out on goodies such as logical properties and the lh unit. If you‚Äôre feeling brave you‚Äôll describe this as progressive enhancement.

And really, why stop at the text‚Äôs width if you‚Äôre looking to make your text as readable as possible? Measure is just one of several typographic elements you can tweak. For example, most browsers set line height (or leading) to 1.2 times the font size. That‚Äôs OK for headings and titles, but probably too narrow for long runs of prose. The ideal leading? It depends on‚Ä¶ etc. etc., but probably sits somewhere between 1.35 and 1.6 times the font size.

Add margins, padding and proximity to these bare-ish necessities. A border here and there to separate page blocks. You‚Äôll probably need more than 147 lines, and the weird thing is you may find you reach a sort of CSS critical mass where your blog suddenly looks designed. 215 248 lines at this precise moment in time, looking at this text. Expressive, combinational magic, CSS.

item.title: ‚ÄúIf Mein Kampf is your favourite book of course you‚Äôre a Nazi‚Äù is not a phrase I hoped to be writing in 2026 but here we are on the indieweb
item.author: mail@thisdaysportion.com
item.description:
Manuel arguing for some specious neutrality and detachment:

‚Ä¶if I tell you my favorite book is the [sic] Mein Kampf, you have every reason to be perplexed and ask follow-up questions. But if you just assumed, based on that, that I‚Äôm a Nazi sympathizer, that would be wrong.

If ‚Äúraising an eyebrow‚Äù is your only reaction to this statement with all [gestures] this going on: you‚Äôre a problem.

Bix asks:

‚Ä¶how do I square my appreciation for Ye Olde Blogroll (where I am listed) and People and Blogs (which just featured me) with his [Manuel‚Äôs] penchant for trying to discuss things from the perspective of a view from nowhere which only can ever look out at nothing and leave us wondering what the hell?

Because the indieweb isn‚Äôt a good thing in and of itself. In theory, I could write a Mein Kampf appreciation blog, add a blogroll pointing to other Nazi blogs, and conduct a set of interviews with interesting Nazi bloggers and it‚Äôd be indieweb.

The question is indieweb for what? If it‚Äôs a means to extricate yourself from the noise of social media, fine ‚Äî you‚Äôll probably gather quite a following ‚Äî but not if you‚Äôre then advocating for politicial detachment and neutrality when fascism is on the rise.

item.title: Excavating Blogger
item.author: mail@thisdaysportion.com
item.description:
Over Christmas and the new year I wrote my way through some ideas on redefining the term ‚Äúindieweb‚Äù. One of the conclusions I drew was that the indieweb doesn‚Äôt have to consist of websites that emphasise the personal, small, cosy or whatever ‚Äî we could (and should) look to include and share writing from journalists, academics and thinkers, with the ultimate aim of helping them move away from US-based intermediaries like Substack, Beehiv etc. (I should also make a belated resolution to not use that word anymore ‚Äî I sometimes think it‚Äôs part of the problem.)

The web bit of indieweb is a lot different from the networks created on centralised, mediated platforms. A lot of the time, its existence is solipsistic ‚Äî no-one knows what‚Äôs in my RSS stream, and I won‚Äôt know if you‚Äôve responded to something I‚Äôve written unless you ping me, whether that‚Äôs through a webmention, comment or email. This is why the practices of linking and subscribing are so important: there‚Äôs no other way to expand our indieweb horizons beyond a few popular authors that everyone shares ‚Äî the indieweb influencers, if you like.

I‚Äôm finding that my stream is consisting of more and more blogging that‚Äôs simply kept going since its early-2000s hey day, a rich seam that needs to be rediscovered and nurtured again. Blogger ‚Äî bought and still just about kept on life support by the squarely unindieweb Google ‚Äî remains a source of just the sort of posts I‚Äôm referring to: erudite, quasi-scholarly, discursive. Yes, it‚Äôs predominantly white (as is the blogosphere in general, or at least my network), and still pre-occupied with early 2000s concerns such as hauntology, but we need more notes on Spinoza‚Äôs four great disciples or the history of ‚Äúpoptimism‚Äù in our streams.

Why is this important? Well, as I‚Äôve argued before, if the indieweb is a ‚Äúcorner‚Äù of the web that‚Äôs mainly for a few tech-savvy, mass social media refusers, then writers will end up on Substack. While Blogger is of course owned by Google, it‚Äôs been so neglected it operates as an old-fashioned looking Bear or Pika, but with a distinct cohort of writers. That‚Äôs good, but not very resilient. For an example, look to Typepad, a similarly venerable, unloved platform that recently gave up the ghost. It hosted Chris Dillow ‚Äî one of the smartest independent economic commentators we have ‚Äî and thankfully he‚Äôs now publishing again. On Substack.

item.title: Adding ‚Äúindieweb‚Äù to the glossary
item.author: mail@thisdaysportion.com
item.description:
At the risk of boring you, here‚Äôs yet another post about the indieweb. Well, more of an update, really. After spending a lot of the new year thinking through and writing about the thing I refer to as the ‚Äúindieweb‚Äù, I‚Äôve come up with a more polished definition, and added an entry to my website glossary.

Glossary entry for ‚Äúindieweb‚Äù.

And if you‚Äôre looking for my one paragraph definition:

Indieweb is a portmanteau of independent and web. It refers to creative web work, such as articles, essays, blog posts, art, video, social media style posts and audio, that is not published on large, centralised, commercial platforms.

Actually, I‚Äôm not sure that is a portmanteau? Feel free to correct me.

At heart, the independent web is not publishing on the Facebooks, Substacks and Xs of this world. It‚Äôs a response to a societal threat.

The Facebooks, Substacks and Xs have spent billions on making it easy to publish on their platforms in a search for fresh blood. It‚Äôs not surprising that publishing on smaller, often not-for-profit platforms (or even your own website) is more difficult, but we could make it easier by working collectively rather than in our metaphorical sheds.

Anyway, do get in touch if you have any thoughts on my definition, or if you‚Äôre interested in setting up some sort of collective, independent publishing effort.

item.title: The indieweb‚Äôs future
item.author: mail@thisdaysportion.com
item.description:
Venkatram asked where we think the indieweb will be in 2030, which prompted me to explore what we mean by indieweb in a couple of posts.

I argue that the ‚Äúofficial‚Äù definition addresses concerns over Facebook and X‚Äôs ownership of our content, and that it represents an effort to wrest ownership from corporate social media to our websites.

  • Defining the indieweb for 2026
  • Amateurs and professionals: towards a less individual indieweb

In 2026 these concerns ‚Äî at least in regard to microblogging style social media ‚Äî have been allayed by the growth of the fediverse. There‚Äôs no longer any need to publish everything we write on our websites, including tweet-length updates, for syndication to other services. Nor do we need to collect and publish responses ‚Äî such as likes, boosts and replies ‚Äî using services such as Bridgy and micro.blog. Indeed, by doing this we lose some of the strengths of traditional website publishing, such as its asynchronicity and detachment from the attention economy.

However, companies such as Substack and Beehiv do form a threat to independent, longer form writing, which ironically appears to have become more popular since the official indieweb definition was first penned, albeit through the medium of the email newsletter. I contend that these platforms and their funders form a structural risk to expression and ultimately democracy through their commitment to scaling, commodification and profit.

In 2026, any indieweb definition should address these threats.

I argue that writers whose living is dependent on their writing, such as academics and journalists, are ill-served by the indieweb. There are several reasons for this, including a decades-old techno-optimism and individualism that values a hobbyist, DIY approach to building our own websites. As a result, when we talk about indieweb we generally mean a group of individual bloggers with some technical nous, rather than the ‚Äúprofessional‚Äù writing you can find in magazines such as Tribune and The London Review of Books and more modern, online publications such as Lit Hub and Novara Media. Yet all of these are independent in that they offer a place for professional writers to publish their work away from the Substacks of this world.

In order to encourage more independent writing, we need to make it easier for professional writers to publish their work away from convenient, large scale platforms. While smaller platforms such as Pika and Bear offer viable alternatives, often they won‚Äôt provide the features ‚Äî or feel ‚Äî professional writers are looking for, and ultimately pose some of the same threats as Substack and Beehiv: vendor lock-in and reliance on small or even single person teams whose values we depend on to align with our own.

I feel the solution lies in moving away from a dependence on platforms to a less individual and less technological approach to publishing. We need more, ever smaller publications that handle hosting, design, content management and subscriptions, and that we form with people we trust and in some sense know. Ideally, we‚Äôd see more spontaneous collectives emerging, where those with the technological know how take a background role to support the writers. Something similar to how we can fairly easily create a Mastodon instance for a few members, but technologically agnostic and without the moderation workload.

Substack famously has a nazi problem, which prompted many of its members to move to other centralised platforms, such as Beehiv and Ghost. As these are structurally inclined to enshittify over time, I expect professional authors to become ever more concerned with the platforms they use. In theory, the indieweb as I define it should grow.

It‚Äôs possible that smaller platforms continue to develop and offer a home to Substack refugees ‚Äî it would help if new platforms‚Äô branding wasn‚Äôt so resolutely ‚Äúindie‚Äù, and they considered the quality writing they could support. The Bear discover feed is a good idea, but it works on a simple upvoting system rather than any editorial judgement.

We seem to be miles away from being able to form blogging and writing collectives. This is understandable, of course: it‚Äôs reliant on volunteering and incurs costs. There is, however, a healthy collection of volunteer-run Mastodon servers out there, which I expect is partly explained by the fact it‚Äôs relatively easy to set up a server. Perhaps this is where new, self-hosted platforms could help, or agreed sets of software. Is this a use for Bonfire?

The fediverse also has a well-developed understanding of the value of independent publishing, and seems to have moved on from the 1990s techno-optimism and individualism that still characterises the indieweb. To be blunt: it‚Äôs more politically active and inclined to collective thought and action.

As for the hobbyist indieweb, I think it‚Äôll grow very healthily, as more people take the time to learn how to set up their own site, and more Pika and Bear-like platforms develop. In turn, this will encourage more people to write about non-tech subjects, which may also encourage more professional writers.

And having read this post, you might be surprised to hear that this makes me really happy. The hundreds of personal feeds I subscribe to are a constant source of interest, knowledge and entertainment. Long may that continue.

item.title: On using indieweb protocols like webmentions and keeping your website separate from social media
item.author: mail@thisdaysportion.com
item.description:
Venkatram thoroughly ‚Äî and entertainingly ‚Äî rounds up the responses to his indieweb carnival question ‚Ä¶where do you see the IndieWeb in 2030, just five short years from now? In it he discusses my post Defining the indieweb for 2026.

I didn‚Äôt get round to actually answering the question in December ‚Äî banging out three longish posts in two days was always a little ambitious ‚Äî but I will try and complete the triptych this weekend. Unfortunately, I‚Äôm back at work tomorrow, and we‚Äôre playing Oxford this afternoon.

Anyway, Venkatram wryly notes that despite my claim that trying to recreate social media on websites through protocols and processes such as POSSE and webmentions is no longer necessary I did in fact ping him a notification using a‚Ä¶ webmention üòÄ

I guess I should make it clear that I don‚Äôt think you need webmentions or POSSE in order to try and recreate the mechanics of social media on websites ‚Äî and in fact it‚Äôs better not to do this. They can make your posting and pinging life a little more convenient, though.

For example, I linked to 29 other sites in my last blog post, and posted a link to the article from my fediverse account, along with a summary. Echofeed automates sending webmentions to any external site I reference in a post, and will toot the link from my Mastodon account when I publish. I could do both of these things manually by sending emails or just writing a new toot, but Echofeed saves a bit of effort. And I‚Äôll be honest, it‚Äôs a nice feeling when a system you‚Äôve hooked up actually works.

However, I wouldn‚Äôt use webmentions and POSSE to post every waking thought and reaction to my website before syndicating them to Mastodon, and then pull in all the responses to my site. Apart from the effort involved, my site is something entirely different from social media, and all the better for not recreating the attention economy of likes, boosts, follower counts and responses. Also, who wants to feed the man all that data?

There‚Äôs value in extricating our blogs from the gruesome mechanics of social media, such as publishing likes and boosts. I have an ambivalent enough relationship with my fediverse account as it is.

Anyway, it‚Äôs New Years Day. If you‚Äôre reading this, thank you, and have a safe, fulfilling 2026 x

item.title: Amateurs and professionals: towards a less individual indieweb
item.author: mail@thisdaysportion.com
item.description:
In my last post I considered what the term indieweb means as we enter 2026, hitting on this definition:

The IndieWeb is a people-focused alternative to the ‚Äúcorporate web‚Äù. It consists of creative websites such as blogs that are not published on closed, corporate platforms characterised by VC-funding, scale and marketisation.

The idea is to frame the indieweb as a response to a threat from corporate platforms, especially those dealing in long form articles, such as Substack and Beehiv. An independent web offers a place for us to publish essays and articles without corporate intermediaries, who, I would argue, pose an existential threat to expression and even democracy.

(Side note: I appreciate I need to spell out the how of this in more detail at some point, and that I can sound like a crazed conspiracy theorist. Bear with me.)

The current ‚Äúofficial‚Äù indieweb definition refers to personal websites, a reference you‚Äôll note I have ruthlessly excised. Why? Well, I feel it suggests the indieweb is a mainly hobbyist pursuit, something we tinker with on our own, rather than somewhere you‚Äôll find ‚Äúproper‚Äù writing with a broader appeal.

A note on amateurism

To be clear, I am all for amateurism, not least because I am an amateur writer. I don‚Äôt write for a living. I work at a university, but I‚Äôm not an academic.

And as the great man says:

‚Ä¶in communist society, where nobody has one exclusive sphere of activity but each can become accomplished in any branch he wishes, society regulates the general production and thus makes it possible for me to do one thing today and another tomorrow, to hunt in the morning, fish in the afternoon, rear cattle in the evening, blog after dinner‚Ä¶

I‚Äôd argue that one of the positive outcomes of the internet DIY culture is that it does allow anyone to write, and that writing without a home in traditional media publications can be better than what you‚Äôll find in the NYT‚Äôs and Guardians of this world. Take The Guardian‚Äôs coverage of AI compared with anything from Audrey Watters, Gary Marcus or Edward Ongweso Jr.

But if the corporate web poses a danger to expression and democracy, we need more ‚Äúprofessional‚Äù writers who are unable to find a home for their writing in traditional outlets to publish on the indieweb. This could be authors, journalists and academics ‚Äî anyone whose writing is a part of their professional existence, paid or not. Platforms such as Substack shouldn‚Äôt be where they end up.

For writers, the threat from the corporate platforms is insidious ‚Äî it aims to make small businesses, DIYers and grifters of us all before setting us in competition with each other, to then be monetised in a marketplace it controls. Read this fascinating interview with Beehiv founder Tyler Den for an insight into how the platforms see what they label ‚Äúcontent creation‚Äù. There‚Äôs no mention of writing itself, or its quality ‚Äî just the ability to create a personal brand on his platform:

This year, we‚Äôve seen tons of these journalists, whether it‚Äôs from The Washington Post or other traditional outlets, where these people have built up these personal brands, they have their beat, they know their audience really well, and they actually now have the tools and capabilities to go independent. I think that‚Äôs inspiring and fun and interesting, and ideally, we can be part of the toolkit to help empower them.

Of course, there are very sound reasons for professional writers ending up on Beehiv. There‚Äôs the convenience, its brand recognition, the ease of setting up subscriptions and payments ‚Äî and the (promised, at least) access to a potentially lucrative market.

A hobbyist indieweb doesn‚Äôt offer these features, and without the resources of a Substack they can be hard (but not impossible) to set up.

But I think there‚Äôs also something in how the indieweb presents itself to the outside world that doesn‚Äôt talk to professional writers. The term ‚Äúindieweb‚Äù itself is homespun. That‚Äôs fine, of course, but I feel there should be room for writing that isn‚Äôt quite as ramshackle, cosy or even personal.

And, just like the mediated, corporate web, the indieweb sees the world from an individual perspective: my website, my domain ‚Äî an essentially DIY effort. What if I don‚Äôt have the time, inclination or skills to set up my own website?

So how do we get more professional writers publishing on the indieweb?

We could start by extending our definition beyond the individual and hobbyist, and admit more actually-independently published authors who are not writing on their own website. Not every professional writer is a brand on Substack ‚Äî there are plenty of magazines out there regularly publishing high quality articles from household names (well, to my household, anyway). Some ‚Äî the LRB, Tribune, Red Pepper, for example ‚Äî are decades old, venerable publications. Some have a history of fighting fascism.

There are also many newer, independent publications emerging online ‚Äî a quick scan of my RSS feed returns Corporate Watch, CrimethInc, Jacobin, Liberal Currents, Lit Hub, McSweeney‚Äôs, New Socialist, Novara Media, Radical Philosophy, Salvage, The Bee, The Lead, The Luddite, The Mill, The Quietus and Total Propaganda, in addition to the hundreds of personal blogs I subscribe to. There‚Äôs a certain melancholy in rediscovering a magazine feed that hasn‚Äôt published for a year or two, but it is a lively, ever-changing scene.

Admitting these writers begins by simply subscribing to (possibly financially), engaging with and linking to their publishers on our websites and beyond. I post hundreds of links here every year, often from these types of publications ‚Äî I also syndicate them (a use for POSSE!) to my Mastodon account (you can even subscribe to the Links RSS feed).

I have some thoughts on a more collective indieweb, where those who have the skills to set up a website simply help those that don‚Äôt, rather than leaving everyone to skill-up themselves. This is a longer term aim, along with the introduction of more platforms aimed at professional writers. The likes of Pika and Bear feel resolutely hobbyist to me, although perhaps Write.as has a broader, more writerly appeal?

Ideally, I‚Äôd like to see more spontaneous collective publications arise. Not necessarily branded magazines, but groups of like minded individuals providing a website to edit, publish and promote each others‚Äô writing, as well as newcomers without the time and resources to do it themselves. Anything that helps us overcome the individualism inherent to publishing on both the indieweb and corporate platforms.

And that leaves just one more thing before I finally get round to answering Venkatram‚Äôs question about the future of the indieweb. My updated definition still includes people-focused, but I want to move away from it being quite as bound to personality ‚Äî and it sounds a bit management-speak, anyway. How does this sound?

The IndieWeb is a freer, more meaningful alternative to the ‚Äúcorporate web‚Äù. It consists of creative websites such as blogs that are not published on closed, corporate platforms characterised by VC-funding, scale and marketisation.

item.title: Defining the indieweb for 2026
item.author: mail@thisdaysportion.com
item.description:
Venkatram asks ‚Ä¶where do you see the IndieWeb in 2030, just five short years from now?, a seemingly simple question which invites a not-so-simple answer. Before replying, I thought it would be worth reviewing what the indieweb is and has become since I explored the term getting on for five years ago.

Let‚Äôs start with the ‚Äúofficial‚Äù definition:

The IndieWeb is a people-focused alternative to the ‚Äúcorporate web‚Äù.

We are a community of independent and personal websites based on the principles of: owning your domain and using it as your primary online identity, publishing on your own site first (optionally elsewhere), and owning your content.

This still seems fairly solid, even if it‚Äôs grounded in a set of late-2010s concerns and view of the web. Ceding one‚Äôs social media content to proprietary, locked down corporate platforms like Twitter and Facebook was an ongoing worry back then, exacerbated by our increasing awareness of big tech‚Äôs role in events such as Brexit and the Myanmar military‚Äôs atrocities against the Rohingya people. That‚Äôs why, I think, this definition of the indieweb emphasises ‚Äúpersonal‚Äù and ‚Äúownership‚Äù ‚Äî it‚Äôs trying to recreate social media through the medium of the website.

I would argue the fediverse has solved these problems, and that trying to recreate social media on websites through protocols and processes such as POSSE and webmentions is no longer necessary. I can set up my own fediverse server, or join one that broadly aligns with my values and choose to move to another should that change, taking my social graph with me. If the server shuts down, I can download an archive of my content.

Syndicating every post from my site to social media is possible ‚Äî and quite satisfying ‚Äî but represents a lot of work for little practical return. Blogs are self-contained entities which are easily shared through separate protocols and platforms, such as linking from other websites, email, RSS and, yes, social media. There‚Äôs little need to stitch together a Frankenstein‚Äôs monster on the site itself ‚Äî after all, this is how blogging communities have been formed for decades.

Furthermore, we could argue that keeping public, social streams ‚Äî represented by, say, a list of likes and boosts ‚Äî away from the writing allows us to sidestep social media‚Äôs structural problems, such as its synchronicity and commodification. There is value in the traditional, separated website and blog, and its methods of sharing and responding.

However, there is no doubt a people-focused alternative to the ‚Äúcorporate web‚Äù is as important now as it was 5-10 years ago. That corporate web has expanded ‚Äî we still contend with X and Facebook, as well as services such as Substack and Beehiv. Some may appear to offer more ethical alternatives, but they share the same underlying problems: VC-funded growth, vendor lock-in and the marketisation of what they crudely term content. Ultimately, all are inimical to writing as a whole, and, when we consider their normalisation of fascism and hyper-individualism, democracy itself.

For me, an updated definition of the indieweb needs to respond to a more relevant set of problems. Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôm going with:

The IndieWeb is a people-focused alternative to the ‚Äúcorporate web‚Äù. It consists of creative websites such as blogs that are not published on closed, corporate platforms characterised by VC-funding, scale and marketisation.

It‚Äôs opinionated, but I think these times demand we take a stance. It‚Äôs also flexible enough to include smaller, but-still-centralised platforms, such as Pika and Bear, even if I do think community-powered self-hosting is ultimately the healthiest approach to publishing websites.

I‚Äôve also tried to move away from the individualism of the original definition (your domain, your own website etc.), which I think reflects the way in which social media, and tech in general, encourages us to view ourselves as self-contained, individual units within a web economy. This allows for joint publication efforts, which I‚Äôll touch on in the next post. I better get a move on ‚Äî I see I‚Äôve only got 33 hours or so to actually answer Venkatram‚Äôs question üòÅ

Updated 31 Dec for clarity.

item.title: Publishing books in RSS episodes
item.author: mail@thisdaysportion.com
item.description:
A few years back I speculated what a book published online ‚Äì rather than just marketed and distributed via the web ‚Äì might look like. Apart from its more fluid, less canonical nature, it struck me that the web offers a way to serialise novels by publishing them in an RSS feed to a schedule, which is what the very cool lettrss does. Appropriately enough, its current book is A Christmas Carol.

The Victorians were great serialisers, not least because serialisation meant an author could earn more money than by just publishing a single novel. Readers also loved serials ‚Äì long Victorian novels are made more digestible when they‚Äôre split into 50 bite-size snacks, and a story with cliffhangers and complete-in-themselves episodes gives a subscriber something to look forward to every week.

Magazines such as The Strand would periodically publish novel episodes or short stories from collections such as The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes. Publishing to a schedule ‚Äì and in response to commercial needs ‚Äì influenced the form of the novel. It becomes episodic, a series of self-contained acts, each with a beginning, middle and cliffhanger end. This form probably reaches its apogee in Bleak House.

Bleak house spoiler

I can‚Äôt think of many finer single episodes in literature than the account of Tulkinghorn‚Äôs murder. Of course, we won‚Äôt find out who committed the murder until a later episode.

RSS can replicate the features of serialisation. In the same way we might have bought a copy of The Strand every week, we can anticipate a new entry in our feed. And once it lands there, we can even control its appearance and choose the device we read it on.

Of course, this only really works with novels and short stories that were written by now-dead authors ‚Äì you can‚Äôt paywall or DRM RSS. The only cost is hosting static files and the labour involved in converting books to atom or RSS, which is trivial if you have the HTML to hand and can work with a static site generator.

But it would be interesting to see a yet unpublished work serialised in RSS. Perhaps it could work with a pay-what-you-want or membership model, or, better still, perhaps we can envisage a magazine-style collective publisher, giving you access to lots of new works for a monthly fee.

item.title: On not choosing nice versions of AI
item.author: mail@thisdaysportion.com
item.description:
‚Ä¶of all the actions a man may take in order to create himself as he wills to be, there is not one which is not creative, at the same time, of an image of man such as he believes he ought to be.

Whenever anyone states that ‚ÄúAI is the future, so‚Ä¶‚Äù or ‚Äúmany people are using AI anyway, so‚Ä¶‚Äù they are not only expressing an opinion ‚Äî they‚Äòre shaping that future.

I read this sort of opinion fairly often in my RSS stream, which may be surprising considering my views on LLMs and therefore who I choose to follow.

Perhaps it‚Äôs because of a residual respect for exciting new tech among folk who, like me, spend a lot of time with little computing machines. Maybe some don‚Äôt like discussion with an adversarial tone, where they‚Äôre asked to make a choice about something beyond its supposed technical utility.
